moves.1. e4: Another short game taken from a Chelyabinsk Variation tournament
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: This is the tournament starting position
moves.6. Ndb5: This seems a good outpost for the knight as it threatens to cause problems on d6 or c7
moves.6... d6 7. Nd5: Now he can either lose a rook to a fork, or exchange knights and then be forced to move his remaining knight
moves.7... Nxd5 8. exd5 Ne7: pressuing the d pawn but notice that his king is now almost completely surrounded
moves.9. c4: reinforces the d pawn, but more importantly opens the diagonal to a4 for my queen. I'm not sure if c3 would be better as that leaves my lsb with a better run should it be needed
moves.9... a6: Although this attempts to move the knight I think it should have been done earlier (before I moved my c pawn).
moves.10. Qa4: Should he take the knight he will clearly lose the rook, however this could save the game for black. If he cannot open some space around the king I have Nd6
moves.10... Ng6: Possibly the best move in the circumstances. I looked at this position for a while and wasn't clear if Nc7 or Nxd6 is the better move.
moves.11. Nc7+:
This at least would gain me a rook.

Black resigned. Interestingly we are still within the Gameknot Database here.
